captions.text:
00:05
COMM: With a few tentative steps young orangutan
Budi, is on the road to recovery.

00:26
COMM: The orphaned ape was deprived of food

by his owner, and handed over to the British
charity, International Animal Rescue in Borneo

00:43
COMM: Every movement the one-year-old made

caused excruciating pain, and he even found
it difficult to sit up.

01:01
COMM: But after round the clock care, Budi
is now able to eat, walk and climb.

01:26
COMM: And even though he is making good progress,

it will require several years or serious rehabilitation
before Budi can be returned to the wild.

01:39
COMM: Thanks to a team of dedicated carers

the playful primate has a bright future ahead
of him.

comments.text:
Baby Orangutan Makes Incredible Recovery

WITH a few tentative steps, young orangutan Budi is on the road to 
recovery. Just two months ago the orphaned animal struggled to sit up on 
his own, but now he can walk and even climb like a healthy ape. 
One-year-old Budi was severely malnourished when he arrived at the 
International Animal Rescue (IAR) sanctuary in West Borneo, Indonesia, in 
December after a life spent caged in a chicken coop. The slightest movement 
caused him so much excruciating pain he cried like a baby every time 
doctors touched him. But after two months of dedicated care, Budi is eating 
fruit, walking and even climbing. ﻿

comments.author: SolidTube911

comments.text:
As much as they seem like they might make sweet companions, most orangutans 
and other monkeys generally end up in the pet trade because their mothers 
are murdered and the little clinging baby is pulled from her body and then 
flung - tiny, cold, defenceless and traumatised - into a filthy cage where 
they end up malnourished and ill until they either are rescued or die.
I think if you saw the terrible cruelty that's behind having one of these 
as a pet, you would change your mind.
